Package com.rb.nonbiz.collections

Class RBOptionals

java.lang.Object
com.rb.nonbiz.collections.RBOptionals
public class RBOptionals
extends java.lang.Object
Various static methods pertaining to java.util.Optional objects.

    Returns a list of doubles that includes only the present items from the optionals passed in (in order), This applies to the special case of OptionalDouble.

    Java 1.9+ has this as a method under Optional, but since we're currently (May 2020) using Java 1.8, this is handy to have as a static method.
    static <T> T lazyGetFirstPresentOptionalOrElse​(java.util.function.Supplier<java.util.Optional<T>> supplier1, java.util.function.Supplier<java.util.Optional<T>> supplier2, java.util.function.Supplier<T> supplier3)
    If the first supplier returns non-empty, return that value.
    static <T> java.util.Optional<java.util.List<T>> lazyGetIfPresent​(java.util.function.Supplier<java.util.Optional<T>>... suppliersArray)  
    static <T> java.util.Optional<java.util.List<T>> lazyGetIfPresent​(java.util.List<java.util.function.Supplier<java.util.Optional<T>>> suppliers)
    This is convenient for cases where you want to retrieve N optional items, but you only want to bother retrieving the K+1-th item if all items up to K were Optional#isPresent.
    static <A,​ B> java.util.Optional<PairOfSameType<B>> lazyGetPairIfPresent​(A left, A right, java.util.function.Function<A,​java.util.Optional<B>> transformer)
    Similar functionality as lazyGetIfPresent, except that it's only for a pair, and it is also less general, as you must use the same transformer function for both left and right item (vs arbitrary suppliers).

    Gives you a nice, structured way to run different code based the 2 x 2 cases where two optionals are empty or non-empty, without having a complicated web of 'if' statements to figure out which

    • optionalsEqual

      public static <A,​ B> boolean optionalsEqual​(java.util.Optional<A> o1, java.util.Optional<B> o2)
      If you are implementing an equals override for an object, chances are you'll need this overload vs the above. The two types A and B may be the same - or not.

    • optionalsEqual

      public static <A,​ B> boolean optionalsEqual​(java.util.Optional<A> o1, java.util.Optional<B> o2, java.util.function.BiPredicate<A,​B> equalityPredicate)
      Similar to the 2-argument method, except that, instead of relying on #equals and #hashCode, an arbitrary equality operator can be passed in.

      This is useful for situations where we want a partial equality (i.e. not compare every member), or where there's no equality operation that's well-defined enough to add as a method in the data class, which is something we usually avoid to do. One rare example is if the data class stores verb classes in it, which cannot really be compared, except for their Class object.

      public static <T> boolean optionalSatisfies​(java.util.Optional<T> optional, java.util.function.Predicate<T> predicate)
      Returns true if the optional is present and its value satisfies the supplied predicate.

    • visitPairOfOptionals

      public static <A,​ B> void visitPairOfOptionals​(java.util.Optional<A> optionalA, java.util.Optional<B> optionalB, java.util.function.BiConsumer<A,​B> bothPresent, java.util.function.Consumer<A> onlyAPresent, java.util.function.Consumer<B> onlyBPresent, java.lang.Runnable neitherPresent)
      Gives you a nice, structured way to run different code based the 2 x 2 cases where two optionals are empty or non-empty, without having a complicated web of 'if' statements to figure out which

    • optionalToStream

      public static <T> java.util.stream.Stream<T> optionalToStream​(java.util.Optional<T> optional)
      Creates a mini-stream of 0 or 1 items, depending on whether an optional is empty or not. Apparently a future version of Java (not 8) will support that, but now I have to write it out.

    • lazyGetIfPresent

      public static <T> java.util.Optional<java.util.List<T>> lazyGetIfPresent​(java.util.List<java.util.function.Supplier<java.util.Optional<T>>> suppliers)
      This is convenient for cases where you want to retrieve N optional items, but you only want to bother retrieving the K+1-th item if all items up to K were Optional#isPresent.

    • lazyGetIfPresent

      public static <T> java.util.Optional<java.util.List<T>> lazyGetIfPresent​(java.util.function.Supplier<java.util.Optional<T>>... suppliersArray)

    • lazyGetFirstPresentOptionalOrElse

      public static <T> T lazyGetFirstPresentOptionalOrElse​(java.util.function.Supplier<java.util.Optional<T>> supplier1, java.util.function.Supplier<java.util.Optional<T>> supplier2, java.util.function.Supplier<T> supplier3)
      If the first supplier returns non-empty, return that value. Then, if the second supplier returns non-empty, return that value. Otherwise, return the value from the last supplier. We could have done this with varargs, but then we'd have to put the supplier of the non-optional as the 1st arg, and that would be inconsistent with the logical ordering of the steps as the caller would see them, because the 1st supplier would really be the last step.

    • lazyGetPairIfPresent

      public static <A,​ B> java.util.Optional<PairOfSameType<B>> lazyGetPairIfPresent​(A left, A right, java.util.function.Function<A,​java.util.Optional<B>> transformer)
      Similar functionality as lazyGetIfPresent, except that it's only for a pair, and it is also less general, as you must use the same transformer function for both left and right item (vs arbitrary suppliers).

      public static java.util.List<java.lang.Double> filterPresentOptionalDoubles​(java.util.List<java.util.OptionalDouble> original)
      Returns a list of doubles that includes only the present items from the input list of OptionalDouble items. This applies to the special case of OptionalDouble.

    • toStringOrEmpty

      public static <T> java.lang.String toStringOrEmpty​(java.util.Optional<T> optional)
      If present, return .toString() value. Otherwise return the empty string.

    • toStringOrEmpty

      public static <T extends PrintsInstruments> java.lang.String toStringOrEmpty​(java.util.Optional<T> optional, InstrumentMaster instrumentMaster, java.time.LocalDate date)
      If present, return .toString() value. Otherwise return the empty string.

    • transformIfNonNull

      public static <V1,​ V2> java.util.function.Function<V1,​V2> transformIfNonNull​(java.util.function.Function<V1,​V2> transformer)
      If the value is null, leave it null, otherwise transform it. We normally don't deal with nulls, but there are cases where we need to (e.g. 3rd party libraries that use null). This is not really Optional-related, but we have a lot of 'transform' methods for optionals, so this is a good place to put this in.

    • transformFromNullable

      public static <V1,​ V2> java.util.Optional<V2> transformFromNullable​(V1 value, java.util.function.Function<V1,​V2> transformer)
      If the value is null, return Optional.empty(), otherwise return Optional.of(some transformation of it). We normally don't deal with nulls, but there are cases where we need to (e.g. 3rd party libraries that use null). This is not really Optional-related, but we have a lot of 'transform' methods for optionals, so this is a good place to put this in.

    • ifPresentOrElse

      public static <T> void ifPresentOrElse​(java.util.Optional<T> optional, java.util.function.Consumer<? super T> action, java.lang.Runnable emptyAction)
      Java 1.9+ has this as a method under Optional, but since we're currently (May 2020) using Java 1.8, this is handy to have as a static method.

    • findFirstPresentOptional

      public static <V1,​ V2> java.util.Optional<V2> findFirstPresentOptional​(java.util.Collection<V1> collection, java.util.function.Function<V1,​java.util.Optional<V2>> transformer)

    • findOnlyPresentOptional

      public static <T> T findOnlyPresentOptional​(java.util.Optional<T> opt1, java.util.Optional<T> opt2)
      Throws if neither or both optionals passed in are empty. Otherwise, it returns the value inside the (only) non-empty optional.

    • findOnlyPresentOptional

      public static <T> T findOnlyPresentOptional​(java.util.Optional<T> opt1, java.util.Optional<T> opt2, java.util.Optional<T> opt3)
      Throws unless exactly one of the 3 optionals passed in is present. Otherwise, it returns the value inside the (only) non-empty optional.

    • findZeroOrOnePresentOptional

      public static <T> java.util.Optional<T> findZeroOrOnePresentOptional​(java.util.Optional<T> opt1, java.util.Optional<T> opt2, java.util.Optional<T> opt3)
      Throws if more than one of the optionals passed in is present. If all are empty, returns empty optional, otherwise it returns the only non-empty optional.

    • findZeroOrOnePresentOptionalsFromStream

      public static <T> java.util.Optional<T> findZeroOrOnePresentOptionalsFromStream​(java.util.stream.Stream<java.util.Optional<T>> stream)
